result.markdown:
--- title: "Tidy work in Tidyverse" author: "Marcin Kierczak" image: "assets/featured.jpg" format: revealjs: df-print: default --- ## {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell} ::: ## Learning Outcomes
When this module is complete, you will: - know what `tidyverse` is and a bit about its history - be able to use different pipes, including advanced ones and placeholders - know whether the data you work with are tidy - will be able to load, debug and tidy your data - understand how to combine data sets using `join_*` - be aware of useful packages within `tidyverse` ## Tidyverse — what is it all about? - [tidyverse](http://www.tidyverse.org) is a collection of packages üì¶, - created by [Hadley Wickham](http://hadley.nz), - has became a *de facto* standard in data analyses, - a philosophy of programming or a programming paradigm: everything is about üåä the flow of üßπ *tidy data*. ::: {layout.ncol=3} ![](assets/hex-tidyverse.png){height="250px"} ![](assets/Hadley-wickham2016-02-04.jpeg){height="250px"} ![](assets/RforDataScience.jpeg){height="250px"} ::: ::: {.aside} Images: www.tidyverse.org, Wikipedia, www.tidyverse.org ::: ## `?(Tidyverse OR !Tidyverse)` ::: {.callout-warning} ‚ò†Ô∏è There are still some people out there talking about *the tidyverse curse* though... ‚ò†Ô∏è
::: . . . ::: {.blockquote} *Navigating the balance between base R and the tidyverse is a challenge to learn.* [- Robert A. Muenchen](http://r4stats.com/articles/why-r-is-hard-to-learn/) ::: ## Typical Tidyverse Workflow ![](assets/tidyverse-flow.png){height="400px"} [[Source: http://www.storybench.org/getting-started-with-tidyverse-in-r/](http://www.storybench.org/getting-started-with-tidyverse-in-r/)]{.smaller} ## Introduction to Pipes or Let My Data Flow üåä {background-image="assets/pipes.jpg" background-opacity="0.8"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](assets/MagrittePipe.jpg) [Rene Magritt, [*La trahison des images*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Treachery_of_Images), [Wikimedia Commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Treachery_of_Images#/media/File:MagrittePipe.jpg)]{.smaller}
![](assets/magrittr.png) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - `magrittr` package — `tidyverse` and beyond

- the `%>%` pipe

- `x %>% f` $\equiv$ `f(x)`

- `x %>% f(y)` $\equiv$ `f(x, y)`

- `x %>% f %>% g %>% h` $\equiv$ `h(g(f(x)))` ::: :::: ## Introduction to Pipes Instead of writing this: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} result <- head(iris, n=3) ``` ::: write this: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris %>% head(n=3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 1 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 3 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa ``` ::: ::: ## Other Types of Pipes — `%T>%` - Provided by `magritter`, not in `tidyverse` - When you call a function for its *side effects* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} rnorm(50) %>% matrix(ncol = 2) %>% plot() %>% summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/magrittr2a-1.png){width=384} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Length Class Mode 0 NULL NULL ``` ::: ::: ## Other Types of Pipes — `%T>%` :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ![](assets/T-pipe.png){height="180px"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} rnorm(50) %>% matrix(ncol = 2) %T>% plot() %>% summary() ``` ::: ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=288} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` V1 V2 Min. :-1.96634 Min. :-1.9385 1st Qu.:-0.60982 1st Qu.:-0.4539 Median : 0.22170 Median : 0.4114 Mean : 0.07356 Mean : 0.2631 3rd Qu.: 0.79662 3rd Qu.: 0.8496 Max. : 2.17988 Max. : 2.6664 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Other Types of `magrittr` Pipes — `%$%` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris %>% cor(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error: object 'Sepal.Width' not found ``` ::: :::
. . . We need the `%$%` pipe with **exposition of variables**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris %$% cor(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -0.1175698 ``` ::: ::: . . . This is because `cor` function does not have the `x` (data) argument – the very first argument of a pipe-friendly function. ## Other Types of `magrittr` Pipes — %<>% It exists but can lead to somewhat confusing code! üíÄ `x %<>% f` $\equiv$ `x <- f(x)` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} M <- matrix(rnorm(16), nrow=4); M %<>% colSums(); M ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -3.598298 -1.504174 -0.698766 -2.299898 ``` ::: ::: ## Native R pipe From R >= 4.1.0 we have a native `|>` pipe that is a bit faster than `%>%` but currently has no placeholders mechanism. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(1,2,3,4,5) |> mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 ``` ::: ::: . . .
even simple placeholder `_` is available now. But üíÄ only for **named** arguments. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mtcars |> lm(mpg ~ disp, data = _) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = mpg ~ disp, data = mtcars) Coefficients: (Intercept) disp 29.59985 -0.04122 ``` ::: ::: ## Placeholders in `magrittr` Pipes Sometimes we want to pass the resulting data to *other than the first* argument of the next function in chain. `magritter` provides placeholder mechanism for this: - `x %>% f(y, .)` $\equiv$ `f(y, x)`, - `x %>% f(y, z = .)` $\equiv$ `f(y, z = x)`. . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} M <- rnorm(4) %>% matrix(nrow = 2) M %>% `%*%`(., .) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [1,] -0.04176768 0.2417154 [2,] -2.44204176 -0.3047041 ``` ::: ::: ## Placeholders for nested expressions But for nested expressions: - `x %>% f(a = p(.), b = q(.))` $\equiv$ `f(x, a = p(x), b = q(x))` . . . - `x %>% {f(a = p(.), b = q(.))}` $\equiv$ `f(a = p(x), b = q(x))` . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} print_M_summ <- function(nrow, ncol) paste0('Matrix M has: ', nrow, ' rows and ', ncol, ' cols.') M %>% {print_M_summ(nrow(.), ncol(.))} ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Matrix M has: 2 rows and 2 cols." ``` ::: ::: ## Placeholders -- unary functions We can even use placeholders as the first element of a pipe: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} f <- . %>% sin %>% cos f ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Functional sequence with the following components: 1. sin(.) 2. cos(.) Use 'functions' to extract the individual functions. ``` ::: ::: and, indeed the `f` function works: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 7 %>% f ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.7918362 ``` ::: ::: ## Time to do [Lab 1.1](../../labs/tidyverse/#pipes) ![](assets/your_turn.jpg) ## Tibbles :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](assets/tibble_tweet.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - `tibble` is one of the unifying features of tidyverse,

- it is a *better* `data.frame` realization,

- objects `data.frame` can be coerced to `tibble` using `as_tibble()` ::: :::: ## Convert `data.frame` to `tibble` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as_tibble(iris) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 150 √ó 5 Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 1 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.9 3 1.4 0.2 setosa 3 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 4 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 5 5 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa 6 5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4 setosa 7 4.6 3.4 1.4 0.3 setosa 8 5 3.4 1.5 0.2 setosa 9 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa 10 4.9 3.1 1.5 0.1 setosa # ‚Ñπ 140 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Tibbles from scratch with `tibble` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble( x = 1, # recycling y = runif(50), z = x + y^2, outcome = rnorm(50) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 50 √ó 4 x y z outcome 1 1 0.568 1.32 -0.953 2 1 0.140 1.02 -0.267 3 1 0.669 1.45 -0.291 4 1 0.267 1.07 -0.439 5 1 0.533 1.28 -0.490 6 1 0.483 1.23 0.851 7 1 0.129 1.02 -0.782 8 1 0.798 1.64 -0.520 9 1 0.946 1.89 0.223 10 1 0.0507 1.00 -0.269 # ‚Ñπ 40 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## More on Tibbles - When you print a `tibble`: - all columns that fit the screen are shown, - only the first 10 rows are shown, - data type for each column is shown. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as_tibble(cars) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 50 √ó 2 speed dist 1 4 2 2 4 10 3 7 4 4 7 22 5 8 16 6 9 10 7 10 18 8 10 26 9 10 34 10 11 17 # ‚Ñπ 40 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Tibble printing options - `my_tibble %>% print(n = 50, width = Inf)`, - `options(tibble.print_min = 15, tibble.print_max = 25)`, - `options(dplyr.print_min = Inf)`, - `options(tibble.width = Inf)` ## Subsetting Tibbles **vehicles** will be our `tibble` version of `cars` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vehicles <- as_tibble(cars[1:5,]) ``` ::: . . . We can access data like this: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vehicles[['speed']] vehicles[[1]] vehicles$speed ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 4 7 7 8 [1] 4 4 7 7 8 [1] 4 4 7 7 8 ``` ::: ::: . . . Or, alternatively, using placeholders: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vehicles %>% .$speed vehicles %>% .[['speed']] vehicles %>% .[[1]] ``` ::: . . . **Note!** Not all old R functions work with tibbles, than you have to use `as.data.frame(my_tibble)`. ## Partial Matching ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cars <- cars[1:5,]; colnames(vehicles) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "speed" "dist" ``` ::: ::: . . .
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cars$spe # partial matching ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 4 7 7 8 ``` ::: ::: . . .
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vehicles$spe # no partial matching ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `spe`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ::: ## Non-existing Columns ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cars$gear ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ::: . . .
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vehicles$gear ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `gear`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ::: ## Time to do [Lab 1.2](../../labs/tidyverse/#tibbles) ![](assets/your_turn.jpg) ## Loading Data In `tidyverse` you import data using `readr` package that provides a number of useful data import functions: - `read_delim()` a generic function for reading x-delimited files. There are a number of convenience wrappers: - `read_csv()` used to read comma-delimited files, - `read_csv2()` reads semicolon-delimited files, `read_tsv()` that reads tab-delimited files. - `read_fwf` for reading fixed-width files with its wrappers: - fwf_widths() for width-based reading, - fwf_positions() for positions-based reading and - read_table() for reading white space-delimited fixed-width files. - `read_log()` for reading Apache-style logs. ## Loading Data The most commonly used `read_csv()` has some familiar arguments like: - `skip` -- to specify the number of rows to skip (headers), - `col_names` -- to supply a vector of column names, - `comment` -- to specify what character designates a comment, - `na` -- to specify how missing values are represented. ## Under the Hood -- `parse_*` Functions Under the hood, data-reading functions use `parse_*` functions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} parse_double("42.24") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 42.24 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} parse_number("272'555'849,55", locale = locale(decimal_mark = ",", grouping_mark = "'" ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 272555850 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} parse_number(c('100%', 'price: 500$', '21sek', '42F')) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 100 500 21 42 ``` ::: ::: ## Parsing Strings - Strings can be represented in different encodings: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} text1 <- 'P√• en √∂ √§r en √•' text2 <- 'Za≈º√≥≈Çƒá gƒô≈õlƒÖ ja≈∫≈Ñ' ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} charToRaw(text2) parse_character(text1, locale = locale(encoding = 'UTF-8')) guess_encoding(charToRaw("Test")) guess_encoding(charToRaw(text2)) ``` ::: ## Parsing Factors - R is using factors to represent categorical variables. - Supply known levels to `parse_factor` so that it warns you when an unknown level is present in the data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} landscapes <- c('mountains', 'swamps', 'seaside') parse_factor(c('mountains', 'plains', 'seaside', 'swamps'), levels = landscapes) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] mountains seaside swamps attr(,"problems") # A tibble: 1 √ó 4 row col expected actual 1 2 NA value in level set plains Levels: mountains swamps seaside ``` ::: ::: ## Other Parsing Functions `parse_` - `vector`, `time`, `number`, `logical`, `integer`, `double`, `character`, `date`, `datetime`, - `guess` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} guess_parser("2018-06-11 09:00:00") parse_guess("2018-06-11 09:00:00") guess_parser(c(1, 2.3, "23$", "54%")) parse_guess(c(1, 2.3, "23$", "54%")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "datetime" [1] "2018-06-11 09:00:00 UTC" [1] "character" [1] "1" "2.3" "23$" "54%" ``` ::: ::: ## Writing to a File The `readr` package also provides functions useful for writing tibbled data into a file: - `write_csv()` - `write_tsv()` - `write_excel_csv()` They **always** save: - Text in UTF-8, - Dates in ISO8601 But saving in csv (or tsv) does mean you loose information about the type of data in particular columns. You can avoid this by using: - `write_rds()` and `read_rds()` to read/write objects in R binary rds format, - Tse `write_feather()` and `read_feather()` from package `feather` to read/write objects in a fast binary format that other programming languages can access. ## Time to do [Lab 1.3](../../labs/tidyverse/#parsing) ![](assets/your_turn.jpg) ## Basic Data Transformations with `dplyr` Let us create a tibble: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou <- as_tibble(diamonds) %>% head() bijou[1:5,] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 10 carat cut color clarity depth table price x y z 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 0.21 Premium E SI1 59.8 61 326 3.89 3.84 2.31 3 0.23 Good E VS1 56.9 65 327 4.05 4.07 2.31 4 0.29 Premium I VS2 62.4 58 334 4.2 4.23 2.63 5 0.31 Good J SI2 63.3 58 335 4.34 4.35 2.75 ``` ::: ::: ![](assets/diamonds.png){.center height="200px"} ## Picking Observations using `filter()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% filter(cut == 'Ideal' | cut == 'Premium', carat >= 0.23) %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 10 carat cut color clarity depth table price x y z 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 0.29 Premium I VS2 62.4 58 334 4.2 4.23 2.63 ``` ::: ::: ## Floating point and `tidyverse` ::: {.callout-caution} üö£ Be careful with floating point comparisons! ü¶ú Also, rows with comparison resulting in `NA` are skipped by default! ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% filter(near(0.23, carat) | is.na(carat)) %>% head(n = 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 10 carat cut color clarity depth table price x y z 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 0.23 Good E VS1 56.9 65 327 4.05 4.07 2.31 ``` ::: ::: ## Rearranging Observations using `arrange()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% arrange(cut, carat, desc(price)) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 10 carat cut color clarity depth table price x y z 1 0.23 Good E VS1 56.9 65 327 4.05 4.07 2.31 2 0.31 Good J SI2 63.3 58 335 4.34 4.35 2.75 3 0.24 Very Good J VVS2 62.8 57 336 3.94 3.96 2.48 4 0.21 Premium E SI1 59.8 61 326 3.89 3.84 2.31 5 0.29 Premium I VS2 62.4 58 334 4.2 4.23 2.63 6 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 3.95 3.98 2.43 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-caution} The `NA`s always end up at the end of the rearranged tibble. ::: ## Selecting Variables with `select()` ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Simple range ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% select(color, clarity, x:z) %>% head(n = 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 5 color clarity x y z 1 E SI2 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 E SI1 3.89 3.84 2.31 3 E VS1 4.05 4.07 2.31 4 I VS2 4.2 4.23 2.63 ``` ::: ::: ### Exclusion ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% select(-(x:z)) %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 7 carat cut color clarity depth table price 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 2 0.21 Premium E SI1 59.8 61 326 3 0.23 Good E VS1 56.9 65 327 4 0.29 Premium I VS2 62.4 58 334 5 0.31 Good J SI2 63.3 58 335 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Renaming variables ::: {.callout-note} `rename` is a variant of `select`, here used with `everything()` to move `x` to the beginning and rename it to `var_x` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% rename(var_x = x) %>% head(n = 2) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 10 carat cut color clarity depth table price var_x y z 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 0.21 Premium E SI1 59.8 61 326 3.89 3.84 2.31 ``` ::: ::: ## Bring columns to front ::: {.callout-tip} use `everything()` to bring some columns to the front ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% select(x:z, everything()) %>% head(n = 2) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 10 x y z carat cut color clarity depth table price 1 3.95 3.98 2.43 0.23 Ideal E SI2 61.5 55 326 2 3.89 3.84 2.31 0.21 Premium E SI1 59.8 61 326 ``` ::: ::: ## Create/alter new Variables with `mutate` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% mutate(p = x + z, q = p + y) %>% select(-(depth:price)) %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 9 carat cut color clarity x y z p q 1 0.23 Ideal E SI2 3.95 3.98 2.43 6.38 10.4 2 0.21 Premium E SI1 3.89 3.84 2.31 6.2 10.0 3 0.23 Good E VS1 4.05 4.07 2.31 6.36 10.4 4 0.29 Premium I VS2 4.2 4.23 2.63 6.83 11.1 5 0.31 Good J SI2 4.34 4.35 2.75 7.09 11.4 ``` ::: ::: ## Create/alter new Variables with `transmute` üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ::: {.callout-caution} Only the transformed variables will be retained. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% transmute(carat, cut, sum = x + y + z) %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 3 carat cut sum 1 0.23 Ideal 10.4 2 0.21 Premium 10.0 3 0.23 Good 10.4 4 0.29 Premium 11.1 5 0.31 Good 11.4 ``` ::: ::: ## Group and Summarize ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Simple ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% group_by(cut) %>% summarize(max_price = max(price), mean_price = mean(price), min_price = min(price)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 4 cut max_price mean_price min_price 1 Good 335 331 327 2 Very Good 336 336 336 3 Premium 334 330 326 4 Ideal 326 326 326 ``` ::: ::: ### More complex ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% group_by(cut, color) %>% summarize(max_price = max(price), mean_price = mean(price), min_price = min(price)) %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 5 # Groups: cut [3] cut color max_price mean_price min_price 1 Good E 327 327 327 2 Good J 335 335 335 3 Very Good J 336 336 336 4 Premium E 326 326 326 5 Premium I 334 334 334 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Other data manipulation tips ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou %>% group_by(cut) %>% summarize(count = n()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 2 cut count 1 Good 2 2 Very Good 1 3 Premium 2 4 Ideal 1 ``` ::: ::: . . . When you need to regroup within the same pipe, use `ungroup()`. ## The Concept of Tidy Data - Each and every observation is represented as exactly one row, - Each and every variable is represented by exactly one column, - Thus each data table cell contains only one value. ![](assets/tidy_data.png) Usually data are untidy in only one way. However, if you are unlucky, they are really untidy and thus a pain to work with... ## Tidy Data ![](assets/tidy_data.png){height="120px"} . . . [**Are these data tidy?**]{.center} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa
4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa
4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa
````` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Species variable value
setosa Sepal.Length 5.1
setosa Sepal.Length 4.9
setosa Sepal.Length 4.7
````` ::: ::: ## Tidy Data ![](assets/tidy_data.png){height="120px"} [**Are these data tidy?**]{.center} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Sepal.L.W Petal.L.W Species
5.1/3.5 1.4/0.2 setosa
4.9/3 1.4/0.2 setosa
4.7/3.2 1.3/0.2 setosa
````` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Sepal.Length 5.1 4.9 4.7 4.6
Sepal.Width 3.5 3.0 3.2 3.1
Petal.Length 1.4 1.4 1.3 1.5
Petal.Width 0.2 0.2 0.2 0.2
Species setosa setosa setosa setosa
````` ::: ::: ## Tidying Data with `pivot_longer` If some of your column names should be values of a variable, use `pivot_longer` (old `gather`): :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou2 %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 3 cut `2008` `2009` 1 Ideal 326 328 2 Premium 326 328 3 Good 327 329 4 Premium 334 336 5 Good 335 337 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou2 %>% pivot_longer(cols = c(`2008`, `2009`), names_to = 'year', values_to = 'price') %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 3 cut year price 1 Ideal 2008 326 2 Ideal 2009 328 3 Premium 2008 326 4 Premium 2009 328 5 Good 2008 327 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Tidying Data with `pivot_wider` If some of your observations are scattered across many rows, use `pivot_wider` (old `spread`): :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 √ó 5 cut price clarity dimension measurement 1 Ideal 326 SI2 x 3.95 2 Premium 326 SI1 x 3.89 3 Good 327 VS1 x 4.05 4 Ideal 326 SI2 y 3.98 5 Premium 326 SI1 y 3.84 6 Good 327 VS1 y 4.07 7 Ideal 326 SI2 z 2.43 8 Premium 326 SI1 z 2.31 9 Good 327 VS1 z 2.31 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou3 %>% pivot_wider(names_from = dimension, values_from = measurement) %>% head(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 cut price clarity x y z 1 Ideal 326 SI2 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 Premium 326 SI1 3.89 3.84 2.31 3 Good 327 VS1 4.05 4.07 2.31 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Tidying Data with `separate` If some of your columns contain more than one value, use `separate`: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 4 cut price clarity dim 1 Ideal 326 SI2 3.95/3.98/2.43 2 Premium 326 SI1 3.89/3.84/2.31 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou4 %>% separate(dim, into = c("x", "y", "z"), sep = "/", convert = T) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 6 cut price clarity x y z 1 Ideal 326 SI2 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 Premium 326 SI1 3.89 3.84 2.31 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Here, `sep` is here interpreted as the position to split on. It can also be a *regular expression* or a delimiting string/character. Pretty flexible approach! ::: ## Tidying Data with `unite` If some of your columns contain more than one value ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 7 cut price clarity_prefix clarity_suffix x y z 1 Ideal 326 SI 2 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 Premium 326 SI 1 3.89 3.84 2.31 3 Good 327 VS 1 4.05 4.07 2.31 4 Premium 334 VS 2 4.2 4.23 2.63 5 Good 335 SI 2 4.34 4.35 2.75 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bijou5 %>% unite(clarity, clarity_prefix, clarity_suffix, sep='') ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 6 cut price clarity x y z 1 Ideal 326 SI2 3.95 3.98 2.43 2 Premium 326 SI1 3.89 3.84 2.31 3 Good 327 VS1 4.05 4.07 2.31 4 Premium 334 VS2 4.2 4.23 2.63 5 Good 335 SI2 4.34 4.35 2.75 ``` ::: ::: ## Completing Missing Values Using `complete` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} bijou %>% head(n = 10) %>% select(cut, clarity, price) %>% mutate(continent = sample(c('Aus', 'Eur'), size = 6, replace = T)) -> missing_stones ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} missing_stones %>% complete(cut, continent) %>% head(n = 7) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 7 √ó 4 cut continent clarity price 1 Fair Aus NA 2 Fair Eur NA 3 Good Aus VS1 327 4 Good Eur SI2 335 5 Very Good Aus VVS2 336 6 Very Good Eur NA 7 Premium Aus SI1 326 ``` ::: ::: ## Combining Datasets Often, we need to combine a number of data tables (relational data) to get the full picture of the data. Here different types of *joins* come to help: . . . - *mutating joins* that add new variables to data table `A` based on matching observations (rows) from data table `B` . . . - *filtering joins* that filter observations from data table `A` based on whether they match observations in data table `B` . . . - *set operations* that treat observations in `A` and `B` as elements of a set. . . . Let us create two example tibbles that share a key: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |x | |:---|:--| |a |A1 | |b |A2 | |c |A3 | |e |A4 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |y | |:---|:--| |a |B1 | |b |NA | |c |B3 | |d |B4 | ::: ::: ::: :::: ## The Joins Family — `inner_join` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |x | |:---|:--| |a |A1 | |b |A2 | |c |A3 | |e |A4 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |y | |:---|:--| |a |B1 | |b |NA | |c |B3 | |d |B4 | ::: ::: ::: :::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} A %>% inner_join(B, by = 'key') # All non-matching rows are dropped! ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 3 key x y 1 a A1 B1 2 b A2 3 c A3 B3 ``` ::: ::: ## The Joins Family — `left_join` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |x | |:---|:--| |a |A1 | |b |A2 | |c |A3 | |e |A4 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |y | |:---|:--| |a |B1 | |b |NA | |c |B3 | |d |B4 | ::: ::: ::: :::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} A %>% left_join(B, by = 'key') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 key x y 1 a A1 B1 2 b A2 3 c A3 B3 4 e A4 ``` ::: ::: ## The Joins Family — `right_join` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |x | |:---|:--| |a |A1 | |b |A2 | |c |A3 | |e |A4 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |y | |:---|:--| |a |B1 | |b |NA | |c |B3 | |d |B4 | ::: ::: ::: :::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} A %>% right_join(B, by = 'key') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 key x y 1 a A1 B1 2 b A2 3 c A3 B3 4 d B4 ``` ::: ::: ## The Joins Family — `full_join` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |x | |:---|:--| |a |A1 | |b |A2 | |c |A3 | |e |A4 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |key |y | |:---|:--| |a |B1 | |b |NA | |c |B3 | |d |B4 | ::: ::: ::: :::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} A %>% full_join(B, by = 'key') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 3 key x y 1 a A1 B1 2 b A2 3 c A3 B3 4 e A4 5 d B4 ``` ::: ::: ## Some Other Friends - `stringr` for string manipulation and regular expressions - `forcats` for working with factors - `lubridate` for working with dates ## {background-image="/assets/images/cover.jpg"} ### Thank you! Questions? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` _ platform x86_64-pc-linux-gnu os linux-gnu major 4 minor 3.2 ``` ::: ::: [{{< meta current_year >}} ‚Ä¢ [SciLifeLab](https://www.scilifelab.se/) ‚Ä¢ [NBIS](https://nbis.se/) ‚Ä¢ [RaukR](https://nbisweden.github.io/raukr-2024)]{.smaller}

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
